div1.p: Carter discusses scientific theories concerning the origins of yellow fever in humans.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Herbert Joseph Spinden, July 6, 1922

2121 California St., N. W.

July 6, 1922.
Dr. H. J. Spinden,
Peabody Museum of Harvard University,
Cambridge, Mass.
Dear Doctor Spinden:
div1.p:
About what you were speaking yesterday: Your idea is that man
first received the infection of yellow fever from a Stegomyia mos-
quito, infected by feeding on some animal other than man.

1/ It would be extremely improbable that an organism should
undergo much of a developement in a host to which it is so extremely
pathogenic (and in which its life is so short) as this one is to man.
Its chance of conveyance to the alternative host, and hence of survival,
would be enormously less than in a host to which it was not pathogenic.
This simply needs statement.

2/ There is the analogy of other diseases: of sleeping sickness,
conveyed to man--to whom it is pathogenic--by the tetse fly infected
from the large game--to which it is not: of Rocky Mountain Fever, taken
to man--to whom it is pathogenic--by ticks infected by game and rodents--
to which it is not. So for Tulare Fever and for Chagas Disease--of
which you will hear in Rio. The armadillo--to which it is not patho-
patho
2.
genic--is a host of this organism--a tripanosome. I could instance
others.

It seems highly--almost infinitely--probably then that the de-
velopement of what is now the causative organism of yellow fever took
place in some animal to which it was not pathogenic--or at least in
which it had a fairly long life--and, having developed its metaxenic
relation with the mosquito, was by it transferred to man. If we could
predicate such a resevoir host for the yellow fever organism coming in
contact with the Mayas--at or near Chicken Itza--there would have been
an epidemic of yellow fever, and a severe one, as might well have led to
the abandonment of that place. If this host stayed at, or returned to,
Chicken Itza yellow fever would recur whenever there were any suscep-
tible people--the “failure of human hosts” would not have “eliminated”
it. In an article in the Liverpool Journal: “Annals of Tropical Medi-
cine and Parisitology,” March 15/20, I wrote: “It would be much easier
to accept the American origen of yellow fever, for which the historical
evidence is very strong, if we had evidence of such a host” (animal re-
sevoir host) “in pre-Columbian times in the Antilles or on the Carib-
bean litoral.”

Note that in none of the diseases I have mentioned as transferred
by insects from animals to man, was there any specialization of the
causative organism, beyond that it had already acquired, needed for its
life in man. Indeed, for it to utilize man as means of continuing its
life to best advantage this specialization should have been on the
lines of a loss of pathogenicity to him. Those bred in man retain their
power to infect their animal hosts as well as man himself and the former
continue as resevoir hosts. There is then no reason to believe that
the animal from which man was--by the mosquito--infected with yellow
fever, ceased to function as a resevoir host to the parisite pathogenic
pathogenic
3.
to man when the infection of man had taken place.

Such a host should have existed, or may still exist--although I
hope not to an extent of any sanitary importance.

Accepting Leptospira icteroides as this organism--neither Welch:
Guiteras nor Rosenau are satisfied that it is--naturally, one would
expect this host to be--as you suggested--a rodent. Rats are resevoir
hosts for Leptospira icterohemorrhagica --a very closely allied organism.
With many thanks for the help you have given me, I remain
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, Assistant Surgeon General H. R. Carter,
2121 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
